channel.title: [C#] Spark3D
channel.description: Well... [img]http://xs220.xs.to/xs220/07441/0.1.PNG[/img] I realize it's not quite a cube -.- And it doesn't rotate properly. There's something wrong with the Projection3D code, which I'll be fixing soon. Yes, I wrote this from scratch, and now I know matrix multiplication :). The ViewPort code only interacts with the AnimatedObject interface, so any 3D object implementing that interface can be drawn on the ViewPort. I <3 OOP + Dependency Inversion. Hopefully I'll be getting it to read data from an XML file, rather than hardcoding it into the Cube3D class. Flame away :D

item.title: [C#] Spark3D
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I could have told you that C++ was faster than Java or C# without running tests or looking at diagrams, although not by how much. Also note that all they had when they ran those tests were java 1.5 alpha, 1.6 is the fastest version of java so far.

And if you want to meet someone who can read binary, talk to some older coders that were working in the 50s and 60s, my OS professor is one.

Read full topic

item.title: [C#] Spark3D
item.dc:creator: @Exception Exception
item.description:
@Exception wrote:

http://www.tommti-systems.de/main-Dateien/reviews/languages/perf.gif
Whatever that is supposed to mean…C++ is faster than Java and C#. Anyway, I rest my case, yet I have yet to meet a person who can read binary…I’ll go back to messing with my paint event, trying to get more than 10 fps at 1280x1024 -.-

Read full topic

item.title: [C#] Spark3D
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Some humans can read binary, some can read assembly, some can’t read C or even Java. There is a fine line between the correct amount of abstraction from the hardware needed for a particular program and the speed you can afford to lose. In the case of games, C++ or Java are good choices.

Read full topic

item.title: [C#] Spark3D
item.dc:creator: @Exception Exception
item.description:
@Exception wrote:

Moparisthebest:

You can be TOO fast, if you write it in binary for speed and then realize that you have made amistake, it’s going to be very hard if not impossible to fix. Speed is not the only factor that needs considered, maintainability, extensibility and readability are all important as well.

Then the fastest thing designed for humans to read should work great, right?

Read full topic

item.title: [C#] Spark3D
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Exception, post:22, topic:155353”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=212077.msg1870570#msg1870570 date=1194319567]
And you have to admit that C will be faster than C++, and Assembly will be faster than C, and binary will be faster than Assembly. Speed isn’t everything people!
[/quote]
For 3D graphics calculations speed IS everything. You can never be TOO fast at math. Updater and bot speeds are purely a question of ePenis, whereas in geometry it is practical.[/quote]

You can be TOO fast, if you write it in binary for speed and then realize that you have made a mistake, it’s going to be very hard if not impossible to fix. Speed is not the only factor that needs considered, maintainability, extensibility and readability are all important as well.

Read full topic

@Exception wrote:

And you have to admit that C will be faster than C++, and Assembly will be faster than C, and binary will be faster than Assembly. Speed isn’t everything people!

For 3D graphics calculations speed IS everything. You can never be TOO fast at math. Updater and bot speeds are purely a question of ePenis, whereas in geometry it is practical.

item.title: [C#] Spark3D
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Only for the misinformed ones.

item.title: [C#] Spark3D
item.dc:creator: @_cake _cake
item.description:
@_cake wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:19, topic:155353”][quote author=Cheese_Police link=topic=212077.msg1862392#msg1862392 date=1194057794]
Function pointers would be sexy to have, too.
[/quote]

No need, in Java you are simply forced to do it the proper way, by writing and implementing an interface.

Java also has some nice graphics-related hardware accelerated APIs, ever check out jME?

Well sure, but you have to admit, unmanaged C++ will always be faster than something running in a virtual machine. I remember seeing a chart somewhere that did a benchmark on a few languages, Intel C++ was approximately 4x faster than Java and C# at matrix/vector multiplication.

And you have to admit that C will be faster than C++, and Assembly will be faster than C, and binary will be faster than Assembly. Speed isn’t everything people![/quote]
For updaters and bot makers it seems to be.

Read full topic

item.title: [C#] Spark3D
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Cheese_Police:

Function pointers would be sexy to have, too.

No need, in Java you are simply forced to do it the proper way, by writing and implementing an interface.

[quote=“Exception, post:18, topic:155353”][quote author=Cheese_Police link=topic=212077.msg1870383#msg1870383 date=1194315536]
Java also has some nice graphics-related hardware accelerated APIs, ever check out jME?
[/quote]
Well sure, but you have to admit, unmanaged C++ will always be faster than something running in a virtual machine. I remember seeing a chart somewhere that did a benchmark on a few languages, Intel C++ was approximately 4x faster than Java and C# at matrix/vector multiplication.[/quote]

And you have to admit that C will be faster than C++, and Assembly will be faster than C, and binary will be faster than Assembly. Speed isn’t everything people!

Read full topic

Java also has some nice graphics-related hardware accelerated APIs, ever check out jME?

item.title: [C#] Spark3D
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

ninja nub:

C++ is so much easier. And it’s compatible with a lot of operating systems. Also, it’s the easiest to use with 3D modeling.

Not necessarily. Java is even more highly compatible on a lot of platforms; Sun writes the JRE for you, all you have to write is the code.

Java also has some nice graphics-related hardware accelerated APIs, ever check out jME?

As for C++ being eaiser…in some aspects, perhaps.

Read full topic

reflection provides a more complicated version of that!

item.title: [C#] Spark3D
item.dc:creator: @_cake _cake
item.description:
@_cake wrote:

[quote=“Exception, post:13, topic:155353”][quote author=Cheese_Police link=topic=212077.msg1862392#msg1862392 date=1194057794]
Operator overloading is one crucial feature in C++ that java lacks.
Function pointers would be sexy to have, too.
[/quote]
C# has them ;p You just need to put the code in an unsafe { } block, and compile compile with /unsafe. AFAIK, they are totally non existent in Java.[/quote]

Righto, function pointers do not exist in Java.
But pointers do, just a really beaten down no pointer arithmetic version.
‘.’ is the dereference operator.

Read full topic

item.title: [C#] Spark3D
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

[quote=“Exception, post:6, topic:155353”][quote author=sh!ft link=topic=212077.msg1856525#msg1856525 date=1193782457]
Make an OpenGL control, and use ogl. Yeah?
[/quote]
Been there, done that. I learned nothing about the actual math behind the rendering.[/quote]

Try decompiling the classes in these applets :-http://d00.cool.ne.jp/metase/mqov/ku.html
(there are 2 simpler ones in the links the bottom)

Simplest example of non-engine based rendering i’ve found.

Hope it helps
